title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique legal and political relationship between the United States and Indian tribes. Indian tribes have the authority to provide governmental programs, develop economies, and build infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and regulations acknowledge Indian tribes as governments. Indian tribes have the inherent authority to tax, operate as governments, and access capital for projects. Tax parity with tribal governments aligns with Federal treaties recognizing tribal sovereignty and addresses historic disadvantages in capital access. Indian tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and governance, with statutory restrictions hindering their development. They are sometimes excluded from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code, leading to unfair tax treatment. Congress has the authority to regulate these issues. Congress has the authority to regulate commerce with Indian tribes to further tribal self-governance and affirm the government-to-government relationship. SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF INDIAN TRIBES AS STATES WITH RESPECT TO BOND ISSUANCE. The amendment to section 7871 of the Internal Revenue Code treats Indian tribal governments as States for certain purposes, including special rules for tax-exempt bonds issued by Indian tribal governments.
